metadata.title: Partial oxidation of methane over monometallic and bimetallic Ni-, Rh-, Re-based catalysts: Effects of Re addition, co-fed reactants and catalyst support

16720 S0926-860X(18)30310-7 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.06.032 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of fresh and spent catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images and elemental mappings of (a–b) 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (c–e) 1% Re-9% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (f–h) 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and (i–k) 5% Re-5% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of (a) fresh 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (b) spent 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (c) fresh 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and (d) spent 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of Ni 2p (left) and Re 4f (right) of (a) 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (b) 1% Re-9% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (c) 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and (d) 5% Re-5% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Conversion of CH4 and O2 over 10% Ni, 1% Rh, 1% Re and 1% Re-10% Ni catalysts at 200–600 °C. Reaction conditions: feed composition = 20% CH4/10% O2/70% Ar; catalyst weight = 100 mg; pressure = 1 atm. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2 yield vs. time on stream on the partial oxidation of methane over 1% Rh/γ-Al2O3, 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Reaction conditions: feed composition = 20% CH4/10% O2/70% Ar; catalyst weight = 100 mg; pressure = 1 atm; temperature = 700 °C; reaction time = 18 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Post reaction TPO results of (a) 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, (b) 1% Rh/γ-Al2O3 and (c) 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of H2O addition on CH4 conversion and product yields from the partial oxidation of methane over 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at 600 °C. Reaction conditions: inlet CH4/O2 molar ratio = 2; catalyst weight = 100 mg; pressure = 1 atm; temperature = 600 °C. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of CO2 addition on CH4 conversion and product yields from the partial oxidation of methane over 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Reaction conditions: feed composition = 20% CH4/10% O2/70% Ar; catalyst weight = 100 mg; temperature = 600 °C. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 H2 yield vs. time on stream on the partial oxidation of methane with and without steam addition over 3% Re-7% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 3% Re-7% Ni/Gd-CeO2 catalysts. Reaction conditions: feed composition = 20%CH4/10%O2/70%Ar; catalyst weight = 100 mg; pressure = 1 atm; temperature = 700 °C; reaction time = 18 h. Fig. 10 Table 1 Physical properties of synthesized catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst S, BET ( m2⋅g−1) Total pore volume ( cm3 g−1) Mean pore diameter (nm) % Element Metal dispersion (%) Re Ni Rh γ-Al2O3 168 0.45 10.8 – – – – Gd-CeO2 151 0.41 10.5 – – – – 10%Ni/γ-Al2O3 142 0.38 10.5 – 10.2 – 7.5 1%Rh/γ-Al2O3 167 0.45 10.7 – – 1.0 9.2 1%Re/γ-Al2O3 166 0.44 10.5 1.1 – – – 1%Re-9%Ni/γ-Al2O3 144 0.37 10.1 0.9 9.2 – 8.8 3%Re-7%Ni/γ-Al2O3 152 0.38 10.0 3.1 7.1 – 10.0 5%Re-5%Ni/γ-Al2O3 158 0.38 9.5 5.1 5.2 – 10.5 3%Re-7%Ni/Gd-CeO2 134 0.35 9.8 3.1 7.0 – 9.1 Obtained in duplicate with a standard deviation of ± 0.75%. Table 2 CH4 conversion and product yield from partial oxidation of methane over 10% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 1% Rh/γ-Al2O3, 1% Re/γ-Al2O3 and Re-Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts as function of reaction temperature. Table 2 Catalyst Temperature (°C) CH4 conversion (%) Product yield (%) H2 CO CO2 10%Ni/γ-Al2O3 400 0.0 0.0 0.0 0.0 500 0.0 8.4 9.3 7.2 600 28.2 15.3 15.7 12.6 1%Rh/γ-Al2O3 400 26.0 8.4 6.1 19.8 500 38.3 20.0 5.4 32.5 600 60.3 34.7 17.7 42.2 1%Re/γ-Al2O3 400 0.0 0.0 0.0 0.0 500 0.0 0.1 0.0 0.0 600 6.7 1.1 2.5 3.5 1%Re-10%Ni/γ-Al2O3 400 0.0 0.0 0.0 0.0 500 4.3 10.7 21.4 19.7 600 66.2 57.3 34.9 31.0 1%Re-9%Ni/γ-Al2O3 500 15.3 10.7 21.4 19.7 600 66.2 57.3 34.9 31.0 700 100 84.0 72.1 27.9 3%Re-7%Ni/γ-Al2O3 500 18.0 13.9 38.4 41.6 600 100 65.1 44.5 55.4 700 100 87.4 92.8 7.2 5%Re-5%Ni/γ-Al2O3 500 14.9 5.7 10.4 25.6 600 42.3 43.1 12.3 29.6 700 100 71.5 57.4 42.5 Reaction conditions: feed composition = 20%CH4/10%O2/70%Ar; catalyst weight = 100 mg; pressure = 1 atm; temperature = .400–700 °C. All data points in the triplicate with an error of ± 2.00%. Table 3 Amount of carbon deposition on the surface of spent catalysts at 700 °C for 18 h. Partial oxidation of methane over monometallic and bimetallic Ni-, Rh-, Re-based catalysts: Effects of Re addition, co-fed reactants and catalyst support Chanittar Cheephat a Pornlada Daorattanachai a ⁎ Sakamon Devahastin b Navadol Laosiripojana a a The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment, CHE Center for Energy Technology and Environment, King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, 126 Pracha Uthit Rd., Bang Mod, Thung Khru, Bangkok 10140, Thailand The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment CHE Center for Energy Technology and Environment King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi 126 Pracha Uthit Rd. Bang Mod Thung Khru Bangkok 10140 Thailand b Advanced Food Processing Research Laboratory, Department of Food Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, 126 Pracha Uthit Rd., Bang Mod, Thung Khru, Bangkok 10140, Thailand Advanced Food Processing Research Laboratory Department of Food Engineering, Faculty of Engineering King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi 126 Pracha Uthit Rd. Bang Mod Thung Khru Bangkok 10140 Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Partial oxidation reactions of CH4 over monometallic Ni, Rh, Re and bimetallic Re-Ni catalysts supported by Al2O3 were studied at 400–700 °C. Among monometallic catalysts, Rh/Al2O3 exhibited the highest catalytic activity. Lower CH4 conversion and H2 yield were observed over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, while Re/Al2O3 catalyst did not promote the reaction under the studied condition. Addition of Re over Ni to form a bimetallic catalyst considerably promoted the activity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, particularly at a higher temperature (600 °C). Re-Ni proportion was then optimized; Re-Ni/Al2O3 at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7 resulted in a significantly higher CH4 conversion as well as H2 and CO yields when compared to noble-metal Rh/Al2O3 catalyst. Stability testing of Re-Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts was also conducted. After 18-h operation, Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst still exhibited high stability with slight deactivation in terms of H2 yield, whereas Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts showed higher deactivation rates. Post-reaction temperature programmed oxidation confirmed the better resistance toward carbon deposition of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The effect of steam and CO2 addition on the Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst performance was also investigated. The presence of a suitable H2O content could increase H2 and CO yields and reduce the amount of carbon deposition, whereas the presence of CO2 showed undesirable influence on the reaction by reducing CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratio. Lastly, Re-Ni/Gd-CeO2 catalyst was prepared and tested to study the effect of catalyst support. The catalyst stability and resistance toward carbon deposition were significantly improved, which could be due to the high oxygen storage capacity of Gd-CeO2. Keywords Partial oxidation Re-Ni Methane Hydrogen 1 Introduction Catalytic partial oxidation of methane (CPOM) for hydrogen and synthesis gas production has attracted much attention, especially in the petroleum and chemical industries [1]. CPOM is an exothermic reaction and requires less energy input and lower capital costs in comparison to steam reforming [2]; CPOM produces 2 mol of hydrogen and ∼36 kJ/mole of energy and costs ∼30% less than steam reforming [3]. In addition, CPOM provides syngas with a suitable H2/CO ratio (equal to 2) for the production of synthetic fuels via the Fischer-Tropsch reaction [4]. CPOM has been widely studied using several heterogeneous catalysts with or without noble-metal components. Although group-8 noble metals (e.g., Pt, Rh, Ru, Pd) are highly active for the CPOM reaction, nickel-based catalysts are most widely used and show good activity. Ni/Al2O3 catalyst has widely been studied and reported to exhibit good catalytic performance for hydrogen and syngas production [5–8]. However, the major issue of Ni-based catalysts is carbon deposition on the surface of solid catalysts, which reduces the number of active sites and leads to degradation of the catalysts [9]. Therefore, modifications are required to reduce coking as well as to promote catalytic activity and stability. Such modifications include the use of different Ni precursors and synthesis methods as well as the use of appropriate supports or the addition of suitable promoters. For instance, Nichio et al. [10] compared the influences of different precursor compounds on the coking of Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts prepared from Ni(NO3)2 and Ni-acetylacetonate. Less carbon formation occurred on the catalyst surface prepared from the organic precursor, while higher filamentous and encapsulating carbon were observed on the catalyst prepared from Ni(NO3)2 precursor. However, significant sintering was observed on the organic precursor. Shiraz et al. [11] synthesized nanocrystalline Ni/Al2O3 catalyst for syngas production via the dry reforming of methane. The synthesized catalyst had high surface area and small crystallite size and exhibited high catalytic activity and stability. Garbarino et al. [12] studied the effect of adding silica to Ni/Al2O3 and found that the addition of silica to alumina supports contributed to more easily reducible Ni catalysts. Ni/Al2O3, hexaaluminate-type BaNixAl12−xO19−α and perovskite-type LaAl5/6Ni1/6O3 catalysts were investigated for partial oxidation of methane by Utaka et al. [13]. XPS analysis revealed that the hexaaluminate catalysts provided Ni-rich surfaces and highly dispersed Ni species obtained from hexaaluminate crystals, resulting in greatly improved catalytic activity. The catalytic performance can be improved not only by modifications of precursors, synthesis methods or supports, but also by doping the supported catalysts with other added metals or promoters. Ma et al. [14] studied the effect of rare earths and other basic promoters such as Na, Sr, Ce and La on CPOM to syngas over monolithic Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The results indicated that adding a small amount of promoters could improve the reducibility and activity of the catalyst. Ce and La could fully restrain the side reaction and gave 100% H2 selectivity. Chromium added to Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was tested by González et al. [15]. Ni-Cr alloy was formed, resulting in increasing stability in methane partial oxidation. Wang et al. [16] showed the beneficial effect of Ce, La, Ca on the catalytic performance of Ni catalysts; Ce was noted to be the best promoter. Based on the catalyst characterization results, Ce could improve the reducibility of the Ni catalyst and could be made highly dispersed within the catalyst matrix. Apart from the addition of these promoters, Re has been previously reported as good catalyst and/or promoter for hydrocarbon conversion [17–19]. Claridge et al. [17] studied Re/γ-Al2O3 as catalyst for partial oxidation and dry reforming of methane. They indicated that the catalytic activity of Re/γ-Al2O3 was strongly dependent on temperature, from which high operating temperature is required. Wang et al. [18] reported the conversion of methane and ethane to oxygenated molecules (formaldehyde and acetaldehyde) over Re2O7/SiO2. They found that rhenium oxide not only increased methane conversion but also increased oxygen transfer to form oxygenated compounds. Enger et al. [19] studied the CPOM over Ni/α-Al2O3 modified by Re and claimed that the addition of Re promoted ethane formation at high GHSV. Recently, we found that the addition of Re to Cu/cerium oxide and gadolinium doped ceria significantly improved the activity of Cu catalysts in the water-gas shift reaction [20]. The good properties of Re as catalyst promoter has also been reported for Co/CeO2 [21] and for Ir/TiO2 [22]. Therefore, in the present work, the effect of Re promoter doping on Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for CPOM was studied. Bimetallic Re-Ni supported on γ-Al2O3 catalyst was tested and compared to 10% Ni and 1% Rh monometallic catalysts. We expect that addition of Re promoter would enhance the catalytic activity of Ni/γ-Al2O3. In addition, catalytic stability test was carried out along with the investigation of the effects of co-fed reactants (i.e., H2O and CO2). Lastly, Re-Ni/Gd-CeO2 catalyst was prepared and tested toward the reaction to study the effect of catalyst support. Characterization of the prepared catalysts by BET surface area determination, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, X-ray fluorescence, temperature programmed oxidation and H2-temperature programmed desorption was performed to establish relationships between the activity and physicochemical properties of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts used in the present work were prepared by the impregnation technique. Commercial γ-Al2O3 (Sasol, Germany) and Gd-CeO2 (GDC; Fuel Cell Materials, USA) were crushed and sieved to obtain the particle size of 0.425 mm. To prepare the catalyst precursor, calculated amount of the required metal of nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Univar, Australia), ammonium perrhenate (H4NO4Re, Sigma-Aldrich, Germany) and rhodium (III) nitrate (Rh(NO3)3, Sigma-Aldrich, Germany) were dissolved in deionized water. The metal aqueous solutions were then impregnated on γ-Al2O3 and GDC; this was followed by drying overnight in an oven at 105 °C and calcining at 700 °C in air for 6 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. For bimetallic Re-Ni catalysts, the amount of Re loading was varied in the range of 1, 3 and 5 wt.%; Ni was added to balance the total weigh to 10 wt.%. The catalysts were denoted as X% Re-Y% Ni, where X and Y represent the weight percentages of Ni and Re, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were measured via the nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments at the liquid N2 temperature of −196 °C using a volumetric gas adsorption instrument (Belsorpmax, MicrotracBEL, Japan). Prior to each measurement, a fresh sample was degassed at 350 °C for 4 h. The surface area and pore size distribution were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. The crystalline phases of the fresh solid catalysts were analyzed by an X-ray diffractometer (Philips X’Pert, Netherlands) with CuK-α radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA at a scanning rate of 0.02° min−1 in the range of 10–90°. A scanning electron microscope (JEOL, JSM-6610 LV, Japan) connected with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer analyzer was used for observing the morphology and elemental composition of the bimetallic Re-Ni catalysts. To analyze the shape and size of metals in the catalyst structure, transmission electron microscope (JEOL, JEM 2010, Japan) was used. The chemical states of elements in the fresh catalysts were anatomized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscope (AXIS Ultra DLD, UK). High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was also used to determine the information on the chemical composition and oxidation state of the bimetallic Re-Ni catalysts. The weight contents of the loaded metals were determined by X-ray fluorescence analysis. H2 chemisorption analysis was performed on Micromeritics Pulse ChemiSorb 2700 (USA). A sample (100 mg) was first placed in a quartz sample cell and purged with He at 400 °C to remove the moisture. Then, the sample was reduced under H2 flow at 400 °C for 2 h. After the reduction, the sample was purged again with He to remove hydrogen and cooled to 100 °C. The sample was subsequently submitted to temperature programmed desorption (TPD) with He at the heating rate of 10 °C min−1 to 800 °C A stoichiometry of H2 to metal atom of 1:1 was assumed for calculating the metal surface area and metallic dispersion. It should also be noted that, after catalyst testing, the post-reaction temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) was carried out to identify the quantity of carbon deposited on the catalyst surface by feeding 10% O2 in He into the system while increasing the temperature from room temperature to 1000 °C (with the rate of 10 °C min-1, after purging the post-reaction catalyst bed with helium). The quantity of carbon was calculated by measuring the amounts of CO and CO2 generated from the test. The calibrations of CO and CO2 were performed by injecting known amounts of these gases into an injection valve in the bypass line, from which the response factors were known by dividing the number of moles of each component with the respective areas under the peaks. It should also be noted that the spent catalysts after TPO were further tested with thermo gravimetric analyzer-mass spectrometer (PerkinElmer, USA) at 1000 °C to ensure that no carbon formation remained on the surface of the catalysts. 2.3 Apparatus and procedures CPOM was carried out in a tubular quartz reactor with high-purity methane (CH4, UHP grade 99.999%), oxygen (O2, UHP grade 99.995%) and argon (Ar, UHP grade 99.995%). In order to test the catalysts, about 100 mg of each catalyst was filled inside the reactor and then reduced by H2 at 500 °C for 3 h. According to the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) tests, the suitable reducing temperatures for all of our catalysts were above 450 °C, at which all metal oxides could be reduced. For this reason, the catalyst reducing temperature of 500 °C was used. Methane and oxygen were introduced as CH4/O2/Ar at a molar ratio of 20/10/70% v/v. The studied reaction temperature was set and controlled by a heater in the range of 200–700 °C. The oven was heated up to the predetermined temperature. Products from the reaction (H2, CO, CO2, O2 and CH4) were analyzed via the use of an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014, Japan). The mixture gas products were satisfactorily separated by the use of 60/80 Carboxen-1000 column (15 ft × 1/8in SS, 2.1 mm ID; Supelco, USA) within the temperature range of 35 to 220 °C. The outlet of the gas chromatograph column was directly connected to both the thermal conductivity detector and flame ionization detector. The catalyst activity was defined in terms of the CH4 and O2 conversions and product (H2, CO and CO2) yields. Methane conversion (XCH4), oxygen conversion (XO2) and yields of H2 (YH2), CO (YCO) and CO2 (YCO2) were calculated from the molar flows of the reactants and products in the output of the reactor using the following equations: (1) X C H 4 , % = m o l C H 4 , i n - m o l C H 4 , o u t m o l C H 4 , i n × 100 (2) X O 2 , % = m o l O 2 , i n - m o l O 2 , o u t m o l O 2 , i n × 100 (3) Y H 2 , % = m o l ( H 2 , o u t ) 2 ∙ m o l ( C H 4 , i n ) × 100 (4) Y C O , % = m o l ( C O o u t ) m o l ( C H 4 , i n ) × 100 (5) Y C O 2 , % = m o l ( C O 2 , o u t ) m o l ( C H 4 , i n ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical properties of synthesized catalysts (over Al2O3 support) Based on the BET and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analyses, the specific surface area, total pore volume, mean pore diameter and metal loading of all the synthesized catalysts are presented in Table 1 . Among all catalysts, 10% Ni/Al2O3 exhibited the lowest BET surface area, while the addition of Re clearly increased the specific surface area of the catalysts. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the support and catalyst samples. In the case of the fresh catalysts, XRD patterns of all the catalysts were determined from the calcined samples. As a result, there should exist the NiO phase in the catalysts although no NiO diffraction peaks were observed in the patterns of the Ni-based catalysts. The results could be regarded as a good indication of the high dispersion of nickel oxide over the γ-Al2O3 support. All of the samples exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37, 45 and 65°, which correspond to the standard JCPDS card of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS no. 00-029-0063). No peaks of Ni, Re and Rh oxides were seen in all of the XRD patterns, which could be due to the low content and small fine particle size [23]. In the case of the spent catalysts, insignificant changes were observed as evidenced from the still existing peaks of metals (Ni, Re and Rh). Similar results were obtained by Claridge et al. [17], who reported that no significant change in XRD patterns was observed before and after reaction over Re/Al2O3 catalysts, which could be due to the high dispersion of Re metal. Metal surface area and metal dispersion were evaluated from TPD of hydrogen. The metallic Ni surface area was found to be 31.2, 36.9, 35.8, 38.4 and 41.6 m2 gmetal −1 for the 10% Ni, 1% Rh, 1% Re-9% Ni, 3% Re-7% Ni and 5% Re-5% Ni samples, respectively. This clearly indicated that the metal surface area increased with the presence of Re. Metal dispersions of 10% Ni, 1% Rh, 1% Re-9% Ni, 3% Re-7% Ni, and 5% Re-5% Ni samples were 7.5, 9.2, 8.8, 10.0 and 10.5%, respectively. The results showed that the presence of Re could improve the metal dispersion and also reduce the cluster size of Ni, which could result in the improvement of the catalytic activity [21,23,24]. It should be noted that Re/Al2O3 catalyst can be completely reduced during catalyst activation at 500 °C as reported by Kon et al [25]. In this experiment, we also activated (reduced) all the catalysts at 500 °C. Therefore, the metallic Re species from Re2O7 could affect the H2-TPD results of Re-Ni catalysts at a higher Re ratio (Re:Ni = 5:5). Based on scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of Ni and Re-Ni catalysts with corresponding elemental mappings of Ni and Re, 1% Re-9% Ni/Al2O3, 3% Re-7% Ni/Al2O3 and 5% Re-5% Ni/Al2O3 exhibited a homogeneous distribution of Re species (see Fig. 2 ); the results were in good agreement with the metal dispersion analysis results. Fig. 3 shows the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of fresh and spent 10% Ni/Al2O3 and 3% Re-7% Ni/Al2O3. γ-Al2O3 support was identified as the gray colored particles, whereas oxides of Ni and Re are shown as the dark spherical shaped particles. As shown in Fig. 3a, 10% Ni/Al2O3 exhibited significant aggregation of NiO particles; this indicated poor dispersion of the NiO particles. On the other hand, bimetallic 3% Re-7% Ni/Al2O3 exhibited a highly dispersed nature (see Fig. 3c). After the reaction at 700 °C, TEM images of spent 10% Ni and 3% Re-7% Ni were obtained as shown in Figs. 3 b and d. Noticeable carbon filaments were observed over spent 10% Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. 3b), which caused the catalyst performance to drop dramatically; the results corresponded to the stability and TPO analysis results. Fig. 4 presents the XPS spectra specific to the Ni 2p and Re 4f of 10% Ni/Al2O3 and Re-Ni catalysts at the Re:Ni ratios of 1:9, 3:7 and 5:5. 10% Ni/Al2O3 showed the binding energy values of 856, 862, 874, and 880 eV. The peaks at 850–865 eV represented Ni 2p3/2, whereas the values at 870–885 eV belonged to Ni 2p1/2 spin-orbit levels [26]. The energy values of Re at 46.5 and 48.7 eV corresponded to Re7+ atoms [27]. This observation confirmed that the catalysts were composed of pure NiO and Re2O7. 3.2 Catalytic activity toward partial oxidation of methane 10% Ni, 1% Rh and 1% Re over γ-Al2O3 supports were first studied for the partial oxidation of methane at the temperature range of 200–600 °C. Bimetallic Re-Ni (1% wt of Re and 10% wt of Ni) was also tested. The feed was CH4/O2/Ar at a molar ratio of 20/10/70% v/v. The variations in the CH4 and O2 conversions as well as H2, CO and CO2 yields over the different catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . It can be seen that the catalytic reaction started at a temperature higher than 400 °C; the conversion steadily increased with an increase in the reaction temperature. Among monometallic catalysts, Rh/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity; CH4 conversion and H2 yield of 60.3 and 34.7% could be achieved at 600 °C. Lower CH4 conversion (28.2%) and H2 yield (15.3%) was observed over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, while the use of Re/Al2O3 catalyst provided relatively lower the reaction rate (0–6.7% CH4 conversion and 0–1.1% H2 yield) under the studied condition (200–600 °C). The experimental results over Re/Al2O3 catalyst in this work corresponded closely to the results of Claridge et al [17], who reported that the methane conversion was slightly promoted over 5% Re/Al2O3 at 600 °C, providing the methane conversion of 5% while higher temperatures (777 °C) gave greater than 85% methane conversion. Interestingly, the addition of Re (1% wt) over Ni (10% wt) was found to considerably improve the catalytic activity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at the temperature range between 500–600 °C. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 2, at 600 °C, CH4 conversion and H2 yield increased from 28.2% to 66.2% and 15.3% to 57.3%, respectively; the values were higher than those obtained in the case of noble metal Rh/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, CO yield from the reaction over Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was also higher than that over Rh/Al2O3 catalyst (34.9% compared to 17.7%). On the other hand, CO2 yield was lower (31.0% compared to 42.2%), which indicated the better quality of synthesis gas produced via the use of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. It is noted that the high CO2 production from the reaction over Rh/Al2O3 catalyst could be due to the partial occurrence of the CH4 complete oxidation, which was evident from the observation of the higher O2 conversion over Rh/Al2O3 catalyst at the same operating temperature. In term of other by-product distribution, we examined all gaseous products by online-GC and confirmed with the carbon balance calculation. No formation of high hydrocarbons e.g. C2H4 and C2H6 and oxygenated compounds e.g. HCHO and CH3CHO was observed in all range of conditions studied. Wang et al. [18] previously investigated Re2O7/SiO2 as catalyst for partial oxidation of methane and ethane; they reported that Re2O7 enhanced oxygen transfer to form oxygenated molecules. Formaldehyde, carbon dioxide, and carbon monoxide were main products from oxidation of methane by oxygen. Moreover, they found that methane conversion and formaldehyde selectivity increased when increasing rhenium oxide (as Re2O7) loading up to 7.9 wt.%. Therefore, it can be suggested from this study that, for synthesis gas production from CPOM, Re should be applied as promoter along with Ni catalyst. It should also be noted that Enger et al. [19] studied the catalyst performance of Ni/α-Al2O3 modified with Re over partial oxidation of methane. They found significant formation of ethane as by-product along with H2, CO and CO2. Nevertheless, the Ni/Re weight ratio applied in that work was 100, whereas the ratio used in this work were in the range between 1.0-10.0. It could therefore be suggested that the addition of sufficient content of Re could promote the CPOM activity of Ni by helping demote surface reduction and maintain active Ni by resisting the formation of Ni2+. Such an addition also helped reduce the cluster size of Ni, which in turn improved the Ni dispersion over the support and eventually resulted in the improvement of the catalytic activity. 3.3 Effect of Re:Ni molar ratio on catalytic activity In order to study the effect of Re-Ni proportion on the catalytic activity toward partial oxidation of methane, Re:Ni ratio was varied at 1:9, 3:7 and 5:5, while the operating temperature was varied in the range of 500–700 °C. Table 2 presents the effect of Re:Ni ratio on the CH4 and O2 conversions as well as H2 yield and other product distribution. It can be seen that CH4 conversion increased with increasing temperature and reached 100% at 700 °C for all catalysts. At 500–600 °C, CH4 conversion increased with increasing Re proportion from 1% to 3%; the conversion, however, decreased at the Re content of 5%. Based on the results in Table 2, partial oxidation of methane at 700 °C in the presence of Re-Ni/Al2O3 (at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7) was the optimum condition as it yielded the highest CH4 conversion as well as H2 and CO yields. Stability test of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7) at 700 °C was carried out for 18 h; the results were compared with those belonging to Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 , within 18 h of operation, Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited high stability with only slight deactivation in the H2 yield (7.4% deactivation). Oppositely, the reaction in the presence of Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts showed higher deactivation rates; the H2 yield decreased from 33.7% to 12.1% (63.9% deactivation) and 67.5% to 54.5% (19.2% deactivation), respectively. After being purged with helium, post-reaction TPO experiments were carried out over all spent catalysts. It was found that the combustion temperatures of Ni and Rh were in the same range (700–750 °C), as presented in Fig. 7 . The amounts of carbon depositions were calculated and are reported in Table 3 . Large amounts of carbon deposition on the surfaces of Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts were observed; this is the reason for the rapid deactivation observed during the stability test. In the case of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, less carbon was found. This indicated the better resistance toward carbon formation by the presence of Re. This observed phenomenon could be ascribed to the role of Re as a stabilizer. It is noted that the ability of Re to help prevent catalyst deactivation was indeed previously reported, from which the presence of Re efficiently suppressed metal particle sintering and reduced particle agglomeration and growth of metal crystallites [28]; in addition, its hydrogenation activity is highly effective for decreasing the degree of carbon deposition [29]. It should be noted that the amounts of carbon deposited were confirmed by the carbon balance calculations. The number of moles of carbon remaining in the system (as also given in Table 3) are in good agreement with the values observed from the TPO experiments. 3.4 Catalytic activity with co-fed steam and/or carbon dioxide Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7) was selected for further study by adding steam together with CH4 and O2 for an autothermal reforming operation. The inlet CH4/O2 molar ratio was kept constant at 2.0, while the inlet H2O/CH4 molar ratio was at either 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 or 1.0. The effect of H2O concentration on the product composition at 600 °C is shown in Fig. 8 . It can be seen that the main products were similar to those from the partial oxidation reaction (e.g., H2, CO, CO2). Nevertheless, at a suitable H2O/CH4 molar ratio, higher contents H2 and CO were observed from the autothermal reforming reaction. Post-reaction TPO measurement was carried out to determine the degree of carbon formation on the catalyst surface. Lower quantities of carbon deposit were observed at higher H2O/CH4 molar ratios (decreased from 1.4 mmol⋅ gcat −1 to 1.1, 0.9, and 0.8 mmol⋅gcat −1 at the H2O/CH4 molar ratios of 0.25, 0.50 and 0.75, respectively). By adding H2O along with CH4 and O2, steam reforming took place along with the partial oxidation reaction. During the reaction, CH4 was adsorbed on the active surface site of metal (*) and forms CH x -*n (CH4 + n* → CH x -*n + (4-x)/2H2). By introducing steam to the reaction, the adsorption of steam on the active surface site of metal also took place (H2O + * ↔ O-* + H2) and reacted with CH x -*n (CH x -*n + O-* → CO + x/2H2 + (n+1)*), which consequently reduced the degree of carbon deposition and promoted H2 and CO production. By introducing steam to the reaction, carbon deposition via the reactions (Eqn. R.1) could be minimized. Importantly, it can be seen that the dependences of H2O on H2 yield were non-monotonic. H2 increased with increasing H2O/CH4 molar ratio until the ratio reached 0.75; steam became less influential at higher inlet H2O/CH4 molar ratio values. This could be due to the adsorption competition between CH4, O2 and H2O on the catalyst active sites [30]. (R.1) C + H2O ↔ CO + H2 Apart from steam, the effect of CO2 addition on the catalytic partial oxidation performance was also investigated. This was done since CO2 generally presents along with CH4 in natural gaseous feeds (e.g., natural gas, biogas) and could affect the reaction and product distribution. In the present work, several inlet CO2 partial pressures (between 1–5 kPa) were introduced to the feed at a constant CH4 partial pressure (3 kPa). It was observed that CO2 presented a slightly negative effect on the CH4 conversion as shown in Fig. 9 . Furthermore, the proportion of H2/CO in the products reduced from 1.46 to 0.97 when CO2 at 5 kPa was added; this was expected due to the increasing contribution of the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction. Post-reaction TPO experiments were also carried out to determine the degree of carbon deposition. In the presence of CO2, larger amounts of carbon deposit were observed on the surface of the catalyst (increased from 1.4 mmol⋅gcat −1 to 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, 1.8, and 1.9 mmol⋅gcat −1 in the presence of CO2 at 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 kPa, respectively). It is clear that the presence of CO2 exhibited an undesirable influence on the catalytic partial oxidation. CO2 should thus be removed from the fee prior to its entering the main process according to the following reaction: (R.2) CO2 + 2H2 ↔ C + 2H2O 3.5 Effect of catalyst support Re-Ni/GDC catalyst (at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7) was prepared and tested in order to study the effect of catalyst support. From BET, XRF and H2-TPD analyses, the physical properties of Re-Ni/GDC catalyst, including its specific surface area, Re-Ni loading, and dispersion were noted to be 134 m2⋅ g−1, 3.1–7.0%, and 9.1%; the values were in the same range as those of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Stability test at 700 °C was also performed for 18 h. As shown in Fig. 10 , Re-Ni/GDC catalyst exhibited higher stability than Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, with only 2.3% deactivation in the H2 yield. Furthermore, in the presence of steam (at H2O/CH4 molar ratio of 0.75), H2 yield and catalyst stability could be further improved. Lower than 1.0% deactivation was observed after 18 h of operation. According to the post-reaction TPO experiments, considerably lower carbon deposition was also observed (0.54 mmol⋅gcat −1 from the reaction without steam addition and 0.21 mmol⋅gcat −1 from the reaction with steam addition). These improvements were most probably due to the higher oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of GDC, which could efficiently oxidize the carbon species deposited over metal and support and eventually prolong the catalyst stability. It should be noted that GDC has been widely recognized as an important material for a variety of catalytic reactions involving oxidation of hydrocarbons (e.g., for use as an automobile exhaust catalyst) because it contains a higher concentration of highly mobile oxygen vacancies, which act as local sources or sinks for oxygen involving in the reactions taking place on its surface. At a higher temperature, the lattice oxygen (OO x) on the GDC surface can oxidize gaseous hydrocarbons, resulting in the higher resistance toward carbon deposition. In our previous study [20], where X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) was employed to explain the electronic nature and OSC of Re/GDC catalyst, the obtained XANES spectra indicated that Re contributed to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. The presence of Ce2O3 on the ceria surface led to oxygen vacancies, which assisted the electron movement at the surface. This led to ease of partial oxidation reaction. In the present work, the redox properties associated with OSC of Re-Ni/GDC catalyst were examined and compared to those of Ni/GDC and GDC catalysts via the TPR experiments. The amounts of H2 uptake were applied to indicate the amount and percentage of reducible oxygen in the catalysts. From the calculations, the amount of reducible oxygen in the case of Re-Ni/GDC catalyst was estimated to be 1.14 mmol g−1 in comparison with the values of 0.91 and 0.98 mmol⋅ g−1 for Ni/GDC and GDC catalysts, respectively. This clearly indicates the higher OSC of the catalyst in the presence of Re. 4 Conclusion The addition of Re considerably promoted the catalytic partial oxidation activity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, particularly at higher reaction temperatures (600–700 °C). The suitable Re:Ni ratio for Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was found to be 3:7; such value resulted in the highest CH4 conversion as well as H2 and CO yields. After stability test for 18 h, Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst still exhibited higher stability with only slight deactivation in the H2 yield (7.4% deactivation), whereas Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts suffered larger deactivation of 63.9% and 19.1%, respectively. Post-reaction TPO experiments confirmed the higher resistance toward carbon deposition for Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Such enhanced resistance could be due to the better dispersion of Ni in the presence of Re as indicated through the H2 chemisorption measurement. The presence of a suitable H2O content along with CH4 and O2 could also help promote H2 and CO yields as well as reduce the amount of carbon deposition due to the occurrence of steam reforming along with the partial oxidation reaction. In contrast, the presence of CO2 resulted in an undesirable influence on the reaction by reducing CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratio. Importantly, the replacement of Al2O3 to Gd-CeO2 (GDC) as the catalyst support could help improve the catalyst stability toward prolonged reaction. The improvement was due mainly to the high oxygen storage capacity of GDC. coredata.dc:description: Partial oxidation reactions of CH4 over monometallic Ni, Rh, Re and bimetallic Re-Ni catalysts supported by Al2O3 were studied at 400–700 °C. Among monometallic catalysts, Rh/Al2O3 exhibited the highest catalytic activity. Lower CH4 conversion and H2 yield were observed over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, while Re/Al2O3 catalyst did not promote the reaction under the studied condition. Addition of Re over Ni to form a bimetallic catalyst considerably promoted the activity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, particularly at a higher temperature (600 °C). Re-Ni proportion was then optimized; Re-Ni/Al2O3 at Re:Ni ratio of 3:7 resulted in a significantly higher CH4 conversion as well as H2 and CO yields when compared to noble-metal Rh/Al2O3 catalyst. Stability testing of Re-Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts was also conducted. After 18-h operation, Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst still exhibited high stability with slight deactivation in terms of H2 yield, whereas Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts showed higher deactivation rates. Post-reaction temperature programmed oxidation confirmed the better resistance toward carbon deposition of Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The effect of steam and CO2 addition on the Re-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst performance was also investigated. The presence of a suitable H2O content could increase H2 and CO yields and reduce the amount of carbon deposition, whereas the presence of CO2 showed undesirable influence on the reaction by reducing CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratio. Lastly, Re-Ni/Gd-CeO2 catalyst was prepared and tested to study the effect of catalyst support. The catalyst stability and resistance toward carbon deposition were significantly improved, which could be due to the high oxygen storage capacity of Gd-CeO2.
coredata.dc:title: Partial oxidation of methane over monometallic and bimetallic Ni-, Rh-, Re-based catalysts: Effects of Re addition, co-fed reactants and catalyst support
